His tests showed high ferritin levels along with high iron absorption. After medication, his iron absorption decreased. Which factor is synthesized by the liver and is responsible for regulating iron absorption by binding to ferroportin?
Which cells can perform multiple phagocytic events and remain functional for months?

A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with acute diarrhea and abdominal discomfort for 2 weeks. Stool culture shows parasitic eggs. Which cells would be raised in complete blood count?

A 24-year-old male presents to the office with an enlarging lump on his neck. Lymph node biopsy reveals lymphocytic infiltration in the germinal center along with tingible body macrophages in a 'starry sky' appearance. The tumor exhibits a high mitotic index and Immunohistochemistry revealed t(8:14) translocation. What virus is present in almost all ⅙ cases?

A 12-year-old girl was brought to the emergency department with complaints of continuous nose bleeding for one hour. On examination, she was afebrile and well. The general physical examination was unremarkable. She had no history except a self-limiting viral flu a few weeks back. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?

A patient presented to the clinic with lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy showed small lymphoid cells having a nodular appearance with prominent nucleoli. The cells were found to be CD5+ and Tdt negative. Further workup revealed (11:14) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old patient came to the outpatient department for her antenatal checkup. On examination she was pale. A complete blood picture reveals Hb 9 gm/dl with a hypochromic, microcytic picture. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the condition she is having?

answers.option: Check for family history of similar disease

question: A man took anti-malarial prophylaxis before going to West Africa. Two to three weeks later he developed severe anemia along with hemoglobinuria. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding this condition?

answers.option: This disease is endemic in West Africa
This disease develops from a spontanueous mutation
This disease is transferred by mosquitoes

question: Which one of the following diseases is associated with the deficiency of ADAMTS13?
Which of the following will not be seen in the case of multiple myeloma?

answers.option: Cast in urine and pus cells

question: A lady presented to the outpatient department complaining of fatigue, shortness of breath, and a pale face. She got diagnosed with the case of malabsorption and megaloblastic anemia. Her reports show increased MCV. Antibodies against which of the following could be a reason for her anemia?
Which of the following cells are seen in megaloblastic anemia?
Which of the following correctly states the cause of megaloblastic anemia?

answers.option: Caused by the deficiency of vitamin B6 and folic acid
Caused by the combined deficiency of vitamin B12 and folic acid
Caused by the deficiency of folic acid only
Caused by the deficiency of either vitamin B12 or folic acid
Caused by the deficiency of vitamin B12 only

question: A man has an enlarged prostate gland which is palpable on digital rectal examination. He is diagnosed with prostatic adenocarcinoma and presents with anemia and pancytopenia. MCV is normal. Which of the following is the type of anemia seen in this condition?

A 6-year-old child has been diagnosed with hereditary spherocytosis and complained of an increased frequency of blood transfusions. Blood complete picture shows Hb = 6.5 gm/dL, reticulocyte count = 20%, TLC = 4000/mm³, platelets = 100,000/mm³. What will be the most appropriate treatment in this case?

A patient presented to the outpatient department with pallor and cyanosis of extremities. The doctor suspected him of a case of hemolysis and ordered investigations. He had both direct and indirect coomb test positive but only at 4°C and not at 37°C. Which of the following is the type of immunoglobulin responsible?

A 77-year-old woman notices that petechiae appeared on the skin of her arms and legs over the past 3 weeks. On physical examination, she is afebrile and has no organomegaly. Laboratory studies show a normal prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time. CBC shows hemoglobin of 12.7 g/dL, hematocrit of 37.2%, MCV of 80 μm3, platelet count of 276,000/mm3, and WBC count of 5600/mm3. Platelet function studies and fibrinogen levels are normal, and no fibrin split products are detectable. Which of the following best explains these findings?

A clinical study of patients who inherit mutations that reduce the level of ankyrin, the principal binding site for spectrin, in the RBC membrane cytoskeleton shows an increased prevalence of chronic anemia with splenomegaly. For many patients, it is observed that splenectomy reduces the severity of anemia. This beneficial effect of splenectomy is most likely related to which of the following processes?

answers.option: Increase in splenic storage of iron
Decrease in splenic RBC sequestration and lysis
Decrease in opsonization of RBCs and lysis in spleen
Decrease in production of reactive oxygen species by splenic macrophages
Increase in deformability of RBCs within splenic sinusoids

question: Which of the following terms is used for over production of abnormal white blood cells?

A 16-year-old girl has had frequent nosebleeds since childhood. Her gums bleed easily, even with routine tooth brushing. She has experienced menorrhagia since menarche at the age of 13 years. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 14.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 42.5%; MCV, 90 μm3; platelet count, 277,400/mm3; and WBC count, 5920/mm3. Her platelets fail to aggregate in response to ADP, collagen, epinephrine, and thrombin. The ristocetin agglutination test result is normal. There is a deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. Prothrombin time is 12 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old child has experienced multiple episodes of pneumonia and meningitis with septicemia since infancy. Causative organisms include Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. On physical examination, the child has no organomegaly and no deformities. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, hematocrit of 27.8%, platelet count of 372,000/mm3, and WBC count of 10,300/mm3. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows 1% hemoglobin A2, 7% hemoglobin F, and 92% hemoglobin S. Which of the following is the most likely cause of repeated infections in this child?

answers.option: Absent endothelial cell expression of adhesion molecules
Loss of normal splenic function due to recurrent ischemic injury
Diminished hepatic synthesis of complement proteins

question: A child had a history of typhoid fever for 15 days. He was given a number of antibiotics including chloramphenicol and antipyretics. His laboratory work shows neutropenia. What is the cause of the neutropenia?

answers.option: Immunological mediated injury due to Systemic lupus erythmatosis

question: An 11-year-old child has a history of easy bruising. Since the age of 9 years, he experienced hemorrhaging around the pharynx that produced acute airway obstruction. Family history indicates that other male relatives have similar bleeding problems. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin, 13.1 g/dL; hematocrit, 39.2% (N= 40-54%); platelet count, 228,000/mm3; WBC count, 5950/mm3; prothrombin time, 13 seconds (N=12-14.8s); and partial thromboplastin time is 52 seconds (27-41s). A dilution of the patient’s plasma with normal pooled plasma corrects the partial thromboplastin time. Which of the following manifestations of this illness will most likely ensue without recombinant factor VIII therapy?
A young girl who is suffering from Epstein Barr viral disease has a positive Monospot test. What kind of immunoglobulins are these heterophile antibodies seen in this case?

A 13-year-old female presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with on and off menorrhagia, bleeding gums, and petechial rashes. Her laboratory reports show the following results; Hb= 12.5 g/dl, platelet count= 350,000/mm3, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)= 49s (normal: 29-40s). Which of the following could be the likely diagnosis?
A dead body is brought to the mortuary, lower limbs are stiff, while the abdomen, chest, and upper body are relaxed. How much time has passed since death?

A 62-year-old man has experienced vague abdominal discomfort accompanied by bloating and diarrhea for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a midabdominal firm mass. The stool is positive for occult blood. An abdominal CT scan shows a mass that was removed. Microscopically, the mass is composed of sheets of large lymphoid cells with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and frequent mitotic figures. The neoplastic cells mark with CD19+ and CD20+ and have the BCL6 gene rearrangement. Which of the following prognostic features are most applicable to this case?

answers.option: Indolent, survival of 7 to 9 years without treatment
Indolent, can be cured by chemotherapy
Aggressive, can be cured by chemotherapy
Aggressive, often transforms to acute leukemia

question: A 55-year-old man felt a lump near his shoulder 1 week ago. On physical examination, there is an enlarged, non-tender, supraclavicular lymph node and an enlargement of the Waldeyer ring of oropharyngeal lymphoid tissue. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. CBC is normal except for findings of mild anemia. A lymph node biopsy specimen shows replacement by a monomorphous population of lymphoid cells that are twice the size of normal lymphocytes, with enlarged nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemical staining and flow cytometry of the node indicates that most lymphoid cells are CD19+, CD10+, CD3−, CD15−, and terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase negative (TdT−). A BCL6 gene mutation is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy has had increasing pain and swelling on the right side of his face over the past 8 months. On physical examination, there is a large, non-tender mass involving the mandible, which deforms the right side of his face. There is no lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly, and he is afebrile. A biopsy of the mass is performed and microscopic examination shows intermediate-sized lymphocytes with a high mitotic rate. A chromosome analysis shows a t(8;14) karyotype in these cells. The hemoglobin concentration is 13.2 g/dL, the platelet count is 272,000/mm3, and the WBC count is 5820/mm3. Infection with which of the following viruses is most likely to be causally related to the development of these findings?
A 35-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug abuse has generalized lymphadenopathy. Which of the following tests would help in finding the cause of his lymphadenopathy?

A 70-year-old man has experienced increasing fatigue for the past 6 months. On physical examination, he has non-tender axillary and cervical lymphadenopathy but no hepatosplenomegaly. The CBC shows hemoglobin, 9.5 g/dL; hematocrit, 28%; MCV, 90 μm³; platelet count, 120,000/mm³; and WBC count, 42,000/mm³. His peripheral blood smear shows a monotonous population of small, round, mature-looking lymphocytes. Flow cytometry shows these cells as CD19+, CD5+, CD23-, and deoxynucleotidyl transferase negative (TdT−). Cytogenetic and molecular analysis of the abnormal cells in his blood will most likely reveal which of the following alterations?

answers.option: Clonal rearrangement of T-cell receptor genes

question: A 45-year-old female with chronic hypertension presents to the outpatient department with petechial rashes. Laboratory shows platelet counts of 50,000. The prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) are both in a normal range. However, the bleeding time is elevated. Which of the following is the cause of her condition?

A 45-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department with painless lymphadenopathy in the neck and axilla. He also reports experiencing night sweats, and unexplained weight loss for the past few weeks. On physical examination, the nodes are firm and non-tender. There is no evidence of hepatosplenomegaly. The lymph nodes are of different sizes. Which of the following can be a likely cause of his condition?
A newborn feeds on cow milk 5 times a day. Which of the following can develop jaundice and pallor in this baby?
Which of the following worm infestations cause severe anemia during pregnancy?
A 7-year-old boy develops jaundice and severe anemia after consuming fava beans. Which of the following is the cause of his condition?

A 25-year-old female is transfused blood. After two weeks, she presents to the outpatient department for a follow-up with anemia, fever, and chills. Her direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following is the cause of her condition?

answers.option: Acute hemolytic reaction to minor groups
Acute hemolytic reaction due to Rh group
Delayed hemolytic reaction due to ABO blood group

question: A 12-year-old boy presents to the OPD with a complaint of jaundice. He is afebrile and jaundiced on examination. The spleen is palpable 3 cm below the level of the left costal margin. Blood CB shows Hb: 8.5, leukocytes: 10,000, platelets: 230,000, MCV: 90, MCHC: 40, and reticulocytes: 30%. Red blood cells lack central pallor. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young boy presents to the OPD with an inability to walk. There is marked swelling of his left knee. His mother gives a history of profuse bleeding following a minor surgery two years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 12-year-old boy has hemophilia. Which of the following statements is most likely to be accurate?

answers.option: His sister must be a carrier
His sister cannot be a carrier
His brother must also have hemophilia

question: Which of the following is the most common cause of neutropenia?

A mother gave birth to a child at 39 weeks. It was a stillbirth and the baby showed ‘hydrops foetalis’. Upon Hb electrophoresis of the baby, Hb Barts was observed. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

A child presents with a bleeding disorder. According to his mother, his uncle has the same problem. He is diagnosed with hemophilia. Which of the following tests will be used to confirm the diagnosis?
A mother brought her child to the outpatient department with a complaint of allergic rhinitis. Which of the following is most likely to be raised in the patient's blood?
Reed Sternberg cells are positive for which of the following cell markers?
Which of the following is characteristically seen in multiple myeloma?

A woman develops a sudden headache and blurring of vision without having any history of such mental deficits. However, she occasionally experiences chest pain and shortness of breath. Which of the following conditions is responsible for these deficits?
A patient presented to the outpatient department with recurrent bleeding, infections, pallor, and jaundice. Which of the following would you find on bone marrow biopsy?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with jaundice and pallor. On her last visit, she was diagnosed with chronic anemia. A blood test is performed and it is observed that the reticulocyte count is reduced. Which of the following could be the reason for this patient's anemia?

answers.option: Viral infection of the bone marrow (aplastic crisis)

question: A 2-day-old neonate presents to you with jaundice and pallor. His mother is B- and he is A+. Which of the following tests would you perform to confirm your diagnosis?

A 32-year-old woman presented to the clinic with complaints of jaundice, fatigue, and dark-colored urine. Urine analysis was positive for hemosiderinuria and the flow cytometry results were negative for CD55 and CD59. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with persistent fatigue, weakness, recurrent infections, and ecchymosis. His laboratory investigations are as follows: hemoglobin (Hb) = 7 g/dl, platelets = 80,000/mm³, and white blood cell (WBC) = 52,000/mm³. A peripheral smear shows 83% blast cells. Which of the following features is most likely to be observed in this patient?

A 20-year-old woman presented with malaise and a sore throat for 2 weeks. Her fingers turn bluish on exposure to cold. On physical examination, she has a low temperature of 37.8°C, and the pharynx is erythematous. Laboratory findings include a positive Monospot test result. Direct and indirect Coombs test results are positive at 4°C, although not at 37°C. Which of the following substances on the surfaces of the RBCs most likely accounts for these findings?

A 25-year-old woman complains of fatigue and weakness. On physical examination, she appears pale. Laboratory studies show a total RBC count of 4.7 million/mm³, hemoglobin of 10.5 g/dL, hematocrit of 37.1%, platelet count of 217,000/mm³, and WBC count of 5890/mm³. The peripheral blood smear shows hypochromic and microcytic RBCs. Total serum iron and ferritin levels are normal. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows an elevated hemoglobin A2 level of about 5.8%. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old man has been weak and dizzy for several months. He has a history of peptic ulcers and occasional black, tarry stools. He consumes a diet low in iron-rich foods and drinks coffee frequently. The appearance of the peripheral blood smear shows hypochromic, microcytic red blood cells. Which of the following conditions should be suspected as the most likely cause of these findings?

A 29-year-old woman has had malaise and a low-grade fever for the past week. On physical examination, she appears very pale. She has a history of chronic anemia, and spherocytes are observed on a peripheral blood smear. Her hematocrit, which normally ranges from 35% to 38%, is now 28%, and the reticulocyte count is very low (indicative of bone marrow suppression). The serum bilirubin level is 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following events is most likely to have occurred in this patient?

answers.option: Accelerated extravascular hemolysis in the spleen

question: A 70-year-old man has developed widespread ecchymoses over the skin in the past month. His medical history includes a diagnosis of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the rectum with hepatic metastasis. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 30 seconds, partial thromboplastin time of 55 seconds, platelet count of 15,200/mm³, fibrinogen level of 75 mg/dL, and elevated fibrin split product levels (D-dimer). Which of the following morphologic findings is most likely to be present on peripheral blood smear examination?

A 3-year-old boy presents with poor appetite and is underweight for his age and height. Physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. The hemoglobin concentration is 6 g/dl, and the peripheral blood smear shows severely hypochromic, microcytic RBCs and poikilocytosis. The total serum iron level is normal, and the reticulocyte count is 10%. A radiograph of the hand shows maxillofacial deformities and expanded marrow spaces. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this child’s illness?

answers.option: Imbalance in the production of alpha and beta globin chains
Sequestration of iron in reticuloendothelial cells

question: A 32-year-old woman delivered her second child two weeks ago. She has been feeling unusually tired and noticed some bruising on her arms and legs along with small red spots on her chest. She reports having episodes of headaches and confusion. CBC shows hemoglobin of 11.2 g/dl, WBC count of 9.9x10^9/L, and a platelet count of 32,000x9/L. The peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. The serum nitrogen level is 38 mg/dL and her creatinine level is 3.9 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man complains of pallor and fatigue. On physical examination, he is pale, and his spleen is palpable and the liver edge is firm. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 8.2 g/dl, MCV of 107 µm³, platelet count of 135,000/mm³, and WBC count of 3920/mm³. The peripheral blood smear shows prominent anisocytosis and macrocytosis. A few of the neutrophils show up to six to seven lobes. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of these findings?

answers.option: Increased susceptibility to lysis by complement
Reduced deformity of the RBC membrane
Nuclear maturation defect resulting from impaired DNA synthesis

question: A 10-year-old boy has developed prominent bruises on his extremities over the past week. On physical examination, he has ecchymoses and petechiae on his arms and legs. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 13.8 g/dl, platelet count 22,300/mm³, and WBC count 7720/mm³. He had a viral infection 3 weeks ago. His condition improves with corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely to cause his hemorrhagic diathesis?

A 27-year-old, previously healthy man has experienced malaise, low-grade fever, and sore throat for 2 weeks. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.6°C, and he has pharyngitis. On examination, there is tender cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Complete blood count shows hemoglobin 12.2 g/dl, hematocrit 36.6%, platelet count 190,200/mm³, and WBC count 8,940/mm³. The peripheral blood smear showed atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 50-year-old man has been experiencing persistent fatigue and a sensation of fullness in her abdomen for the past several months. Clinical and laboratory features are suggestive of chronic myeloid leukemia. Which of the following molecular tests is considered the most definitive for diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia?

A 13-year-old girl has had nosebleeds, easy bruising, and increased bleeding with her menstrual periods for the past 4 months. She is afebrile. She has scattered petechiae over her distal extremities. There is no organomegaly. A complete blood count shows normal parameters. The partial thromboplastin time (APTT) shows prolonged results. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 2-month-old boy presents with bleeding from the circumcision wound. He has a positive history of bleeding on umbilical stump shedding for which he needed a unit of fresh frozen plasma. His platelets count is 295x10⁹/L, PT is 12 s (control 12 s), and aPTT is 92 s (control 24 s). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12-year-old boy presents with increasing abdominal distention and pain. An abdominal CT scan shows a 7-cm mass involving the ileocecal region of the intestine. Surgery is performed to remove the mass. Histologic examination of the mass shows sheets of intermediate-sized lymphoid cells with a high mitotic rate, multiple coarse chromatin, several nucleoli, and many mitoses. Cytogenetic analysis of the cells from the mass shows a t(8;14) karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy presents with fever. In the past 2 days, several large ecchymoses have appeared on the right thigh and left shoulder. CBC shows hemoglobin, 10.2 g/dL; platelet count, 45,000 x 10⁹/L; and WBC count, 13.9 x 10³/L. Examination of the peripheral blood smear shows blasts that lack peroxidase-positive granules, but contain PAS-positive granules and stain positively for deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT+). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old male presented with pallor, weakness, and yellow discoloration of the sclera. Examination shows anemia +++, jaundice +++, and splenomegaly 4 fingers below the costal margin. Laboratory findings show Hb, 6.3; WBCs, 13.2x10^9/L; platelets, 432x10^9/L; total bilirubin, 7.0; direct bilirubin, 0.5; indirect bilirubin; and SGPT, 12. He was diagnosed with G6PD deficiency. Which of the following statements is not true regarding G6PD?

answers.option: Heinz Bodies on methyl blue stain
Favorable lyonization leads to expression of disease in females

question: A 40-year-old male, a diagnosed case of liver cirrhosis due to hepatitis C, is admitted to the medical ward with a history of hematemesis. Investigations show CBC: Hb 7 g/dL, WBC 8.2x10^9/L, platelets 52x10^9, prothrombin time 20 s (control 11 s). Which of the following factors is not assessed by prothrombin time?
A 6-year-old boy with loose stools develops hemolytic uremic syndrome. What is the most likely causative organism?

A 17-year-old female presents to the hematologist with complaints of episodes of epistaxis and gum bleeding for the last one month. She has a history of bleeding from other sites. She looks mildly pale on examination with no lymphadenopathy or gum hypertrophy. A complete blood count reveals thrombocytopenia and a platelet count of 8000/microlitre. The bone marrow aspirate reveals an increase in megakaryocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 6-year-old boy presents with history of fever and bloody diarrhea for the last 1 week. She has also had pallor and oliguria for one day. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin 5.5 gm/dL, TLC 6500/microlitre, platelets 30,000/mm³, and increased urea and creatinine. Peripheral smear shows target cells and schistocytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A three-and-a-half-year-old male child was brought to the outpatient department with complaints of progressive pallor, lethargy, and easy fatigability. He is on cow's milk 5 times per day. Family history is unremarkable. On examination, the patient is anemic having no visceromegaly. CBC showed Hb: 6 gm/dl, MCV: 64 fl, TLC 6.4/μL, and platelets: 450/μL. What is the most likely cause of anemia?

A six-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever for three days, lethargy for two days, and bleeding from the nose and rectum since morning. On examination, he has bruises and petechial rashes all over the body with increased heart rate low blood pressure, and poor peripheral pulses. CBC results show HB%: 9 g/dl, TLC: 29000/ul & platelets 15000/ul, aPT: 25 s and aPTT: 75 s. What is the most likely diagnosis?
